nodes.bodyText: I do not think that this is true ..

according to the HTTP Management API, the request body is required. However, none of its properties are mandatory, so I wonder why that is. The user guide posts an empty request for creating a Tenant. The existing implementation does not require a request body. FMPOV we need to do some tidying up before we can proceed.

This is a valid concern that I think we need fix in a separate issue (#1736). I aligned new implementation to the current one and we should fix both of them, once we decide on the approach we want to take.
Maybe this can moved to AbstractHttpEndpoint as the other endpoints do the same check ?

I was putting those in Util class so far, but as @sophokles73 suggested we can introduce a new abstract class with all these methods, to keep AbstractHttpEndpoint free of device registry abstractions.
Are you sure that you want to deprecate this newly created class?
is this supposed to be overridden?
IMHO we should have a better message for the case where the client didn't provide an ID
the orElse method seems to suggest that the id can actually be null but that is not the case, is it?
It is null when operation fails ... It's used like that across different services and implementations ... Let's revisit this after we refactor all services in an effort to clean/improve this code.
is this supposed to be overridden?

can you please review the method's description in the JavaDoc? I don't think that it reflects the behavior of this method. It refers to a returned handler but the method returns void. It also doesn't mention that the body is only written and the handler is only invoked if the status code is 201 Created. IMHO the status code to check for should also be passed in as a parameter in order to make this method more useful. WDYT?
